Comments_List: Stronger substantive knowledge of current major Europe-wide issues, such as the single currency and migration; of how the EU's institutions functions; and of perspectives on reform of the EU.
History and current politics of the EU

There was a good academic theoretical perspective to the content, and I found putting the practitioner perspectives in the course alongside academic very interesting - the books by MacShane and Verhofstadt were both able to show how political actors thought about the EU and key issues. I wonder whether chapter-length perspectives from those might do better sprinkled through the syllabus rather than book-length in one week each. And for that matter maybe exposure to the direct critiques from political actors on the other side? 

The instructor's inclusion of commentary on current events at the start - e.g. Catalonia, the Brexit negotiations - was insightful, and he brought an evident volume of knowledge on whatever was happening at any given time.

Subsequent discussions tended to be very free-form, which sometimes could be good and sometimes could wander or drag. Maybe dividing the subject into sections somehow at the start and going through them sequentially might help? All that said, I learned a lot from the discussions and there was a really varied set of perspectives and experiences in the class - more than has been typical in most of my classes.
Yes, it was very informative and fun, and Prof. Cameron is great
